photo.description: this is what happen when one derives from the white line... ---- Anselm Kiefer "Monumenta" in "Le Grand Palais", Paris. year 2007. ---- The very last pic (THERE WILL BE NO MORE EVER) of this set. special dedication to Trane. I remember you like this series, and this is usually the hour you start publishing pictures on flickr as well :-). maybe you'll be the first commenting that one :-).

photo.description: From december 18th til the 31st 2008 a video-art exhibition is taking place in the Grand Palais of Paris. The place is opening at night from 5pm til 1am the next morning to deliver an amazing, unexpected, puzzling, and fascinating experience to its visitors. here a visitor enjoying the view from an elevated plateform set in the middle of the Grand Palais.
photo.title: Dans la nuit, des images @ Le Grand Palais

photo.description: Promenade, of Richard Serra. 2008 Edition of the Monumenta Exhibition in Le Grand Palais (Paris). the size of those standing steel plates are beyond imagination : - 17 meters high - 4 meters wide - 13 centimeters thick. They could just squeeze you on the ground like a fly on a wall if they would fall onto you. an impression that is enhanced by the fact that they have been planted in the ground with a slight inclination. View On Black
photo.tags: richardserra monumenta 2008 grand palais paris france nuitdesmusées promenade modernart art sculpture experience journalism journalisme
photo.title: 13 centimeters of "thickness"

photo.description: By Felix Gonzalez-Torres (1957-1996). The entrance of the "Grand Palais" was covered with thousands of candys, each packed in a silver paper. It is called a sculptured-offering by its author because people could take some ; the spectator then became actor in the art piece transformation & disparition... --> It mustn't have last long if everybody was acting like this little girl :-)) P.S. : candy's were tasting pineapple ;-P
photo.tags: nuitblanche2006 paris events modernart night
photo.title: Untitled (Placebo), 1991

photo.description: Paris, Saturday 17th of may 2008. Tonight was the 4th edition of the night of the museums in France (and in Europe). During one night, several museums opened their doors and enable their visitors to freely enjoy their exposition... for zero bucks :-). I went to the Grand Palais to enjoy this year edition of Monumenta. Last year, Anselm Kieffer used the place to build his bunkers of art. This year, Richard Serra seed 5 huge monoliths into the Grand Palais' ground. The installation - very 2001 A Space Odissey alike - is called Promenade... the visitors seemed to truly enjoy it :-). Funny that i'm posting that after the iranian towers of silence... :-)
photo.tags: richardserra monumenta 2008 grand palais paris france nuitdesmusées promenade modernart art explore journalism journalisme
photo.title: Monumenta 2008 : Promenade (Richard Serra)

photo.description: hold on your breath a second on that one.

photo.description: today i finally picked my camera out for shooting the latest edition of the modern art exhibition "La Force de l'Art" taking place in "Le Grand Palais" in Paris until June. i hadn't shot anything serious since... early mars... not to say early february. Olivier Bardin, Exhibition, 2009 in La Force de l'Art 02, Grand Palais, Paris

photo.title: La Force de l'Art (Edition 2009)

photo.title: La Force de l'Art (Edition 2009)

photo.description: this was a set of 120 praying chairs with pictures of people with a tear added on everyone. It was made by the italian artist Francesco Vezzoli and this art piece was called La 120 Sedute di Sodoma. The picture was taken during the modern art exhibition that took place in "Le Grand Palais" in Paris this summer. I like its sadness.
photo.tags: sadness modernart francescovezzoli laforcedelart
photo.title: I remember the shiny tears...

photo.description: today is the last day of the 2010 edition of the yearly modern art exhibition in Le Grand Palais (Paris). This year edition was featuring French artist Christian Boltanski who has used thousands of second-hand clothes to build a pyramid of it. A mechanical hand is randomly picking up some of the clothes to throw them. I've always been fascinated by Boltanski's artwork. I always felt deeply understanding his obsessions of passing of time, memory, death...
photo.tags: monumenta 2010 personnes christianboltanski modernart contemporaryart exhibition
photo.title: Personnes (Christian Boltanski, Monumenta 2010)

photo.description: This guy did not dare to enter in this room. his reaction, like many people in front of a modern art work or installation is very common. I really think people don't know how to handle with those kind of art though it is - in my opinion - much easier to read & understand an art piece of the XXth century rather than older ones... just dive into it, immerse yourself into it, its universe, analyse your feelings about all this and there you go : you already start to make your opinion on what the message the artist wanted to convey... Older stuff like paintings of the XVth and so on are so full of artistical guidelines of their time that they are impossible to really appreciate if you're not an expert or helped in the process... while modern art really stands on its own. Well, concerning that guy, this installation sure remained a big red box full of mysteries...
photo.tags: laforcedelart paris legrandpalais art artcontemporain modernart exhibition expo exposition
photo.title: The outside man

photo.description: Lors de l'exposition nationale Russe qui s'est tenue au Grand Palais à Paris, en juin dernier. Le ballet sur glace Casse-Noisette (The Nutcracker), qui s'est tenu après le défié de mode. D'autres photos des shows dans les commentaires ici. During the Russian national exhibition at the Grand Palais in Paris in June. In background, one of the giant matryoshka of the exhibition. The ice ballet The Nutcracker, which was held after the fashion show. Additional photos of these shows in the comments here. Canon EOS 40D + A.Schacht Travenar 135mm f/3.5. Large on Dark The Largest

photo.description: Richard Serra's "Promenade" was featured at the Grand Palais in Paris as part of the venue's annual Monumenta series. A visitor listens to one of the steel plates, which had a kind of low rumble. The spectators were as much a part of the installation as the plates themselves. Watching people respond to the work was as fun as looking at the work itself. People hugged, caressed, listened, tapped, leaned and slid along the plates.
photo.tags: steel rust texture grandpalais richardserra monumenta art contemporary favorite sky deathstar promenade blur sculpture
photo.title: Can you hear it?

photo.description: Richard Serra's "Promenade" was featured at the Grand Palais in Paris as part of the venue's annual Monumenta series. On Thursday evenings, modern dance classes encouraged visitors to flow through the space. Wacky fun.

photo.description: Richard Serra's "Promenade" was featured at the Grand Palais in Paris as part of the venue's annual Monumenta series. Despite its rough appearance, the surface of the plates was silky smooth. The texture was irresistible; visitors touched them constantly.
photo.tags: richardserra pavement monumenta grandpalais windows glass art contemporary steel promenade sculpture
photo.title: Texture

photo.description: Richard Serra's "Promenade" was featured at the Grand Palais in Paris as part of the venue's annual Monumenta series. The massive plates felt like giant yardsticks that suddenly put a scale to the enormous hall. The room took on even grander dimensions as a result.
photo.tags: richardserra pavement monumenta grandpalais windows glass art contemporary steel promenade sculpture
photo.title: Span

photo.description: Richard Serra's "Promenade" was featured at the Grand Palais in Paris as part of the venue's annual Monumenta series. One of the most interesting things about the work was how it changed from moment to moment as the sun moved across the hall, casting shadows on the work, which it turn cast shadows on the viewer.
photo.tags: steel rust texture grandpalais richardserra monumenta art contemporary promenade blur sculpture
photo.title: Diagonal

photo.description: Richard Serra's "Promenade" was featured at the Grand Palais in Paris as part of the venue's annual Monumenta series. Despite its rough appearance, the surface of the plates was silky smooth. The texture was irresistible; visitors touched them constantly.

photo.title: Monumenta

photo.description: Richard Serra's "Promenade" was featured at the Grand Palais in Paris as part of the venue's annual Monumenta series. One of the most interesting things about the work was how it changed from moment to moment as the sun moved across the hall, casting shadows on the work, which it turn cast shadows on the viewer.
photo.tags: sunlight shadows steel glass rust richardserra grandpalais windows contemporary art promenade sculpture
photo.title: Sky scraper

photo.description: Richard Serra's "Promenade" was featured at the Grand Palais in Paris as part of the venue's annual Monumenta series. The spectators were as much a part of the installation as the plates themselves. Watching people respond to the work was as fun as looking at the work itself. People hugged, caressed, listened, tapped, leaned and slid along the plates.
photo.tags: sunlight shadows steel glass rust richardserra grandpalais windows monumenta art contemporary favorite promenade sculpture
photo.title: Touch

photo.title: Jeff Mills mixe au Grand Palais

photo.description: In the interviews he gave to journalists, Richard Serra said that he wanted his visitors to live a private experience inside a public area filled with many other people. They would thus not only live their own experience but also share this experience with the other people walking around them. This experience the artist was looking for, gave its title to this installation : "Promenade".
photo.tags: richardserra monumenta 2008 grand palais paris france nuitdesmusées promenade modernart art sculpture experience journalism journalisme

photo.title: His Almighty...

photo.description: From december 18th til the 31st 2008 a video-art exhibition is taking place in the Grand Palais of Paris. The place is opening at night from 5pm til 1am the next morning to deliver an amazing, unexpected, puzzling, and fascinating experience to its visitors. Best video-art piece coming from all Europe are exposed there, and it was even more fascinating to watch them while listening to the mix of Jeff Mills at the same time...
photo.tags: art modern videoa modernart videoart contemporaryart legrandpalais paris exhibition
photo.title: Dans la nuit des images - Le Grand Palais

photo.description: She posts at night, it is more discreet and nobody can see her doing. The darkness of her pictures enlight my heart and soul. So now there is no more mystery I'm dedicating this picture to *Kiana* Im on your side Nowhere to hide Trapdoors that open I spiral down Radiohead - in limbo

photo.title: in limbo

photo.description: By Felix Gonzalez-Torres (1957-1996). The entrance of the "Grand Palais" was covered with thousands of candys, each packed in a silver paper. It is called a sculptured-offering by its author because people could take some ; the spectator then became actor in the art piece transformation & disparition... P.S. : candy's were tasting pineapple ;-P
photo.tags: nuitblanche2006 paris events modernart night
photo.title: Untitled (Placebo), 1991

photo.description: that one was called Sternenfall (Stars falling).

photo.title: Monumenta - the forbidden library

photo.description: Taken on the Monumenta website. An article about Space and body : How do we situate our bodies in space? How does space determine the way our bodies look and feel? What is perception? And how can art alter the way we perceive the world? Key questions which have underpinned the work of numerous artists, and which force us to take a more perceptive look at our surroundings, and ourselves. Richard Serra has referred to his work's vocation to reconfigure the space around us, while at the same time altering our perceptions of our own bodies. The sensual, physical discovery of a work of art allows each of us to experience a unique encounter. This physical sensation takes us beyond the straightforward visual contemplation of the work, beyond merely seeing, to feeling, walking within the space of the work, and experiencing it as a whole. ----- here 2 people standing in front of a Richard Serra's monolith. the slightly shake blur give it a touch of uncertainty... Flickr white background is really shitty with those Monumenta pictures, take your time enjoying "Promenade" On Black.
photo.tags: richardserra monumenta 2008 grand palais paris france nuitdesmusées promenade modernart 2by2 journalism journalisme

photo.description: Taken on the Monumenta website. An article about Metal : Steel is first among Richard Serra's preferred materials. Metal is enormously important in Serra's work – the artist worked in a steel foundry as a young man, and has shown a extraordinary fascination for the medium (as with lead and rubber, early in his career), a far cry from the 'noble' materials of classical sculpture. A key material for the construction industry, steel dates back to the industrial revolution, since when it has fostered a host of manufacturing techniques and applications. Steel has become emblematic of the march of modernity, of 'work in progress'. [...] but above all its unique formal qualities, its capacity to be deployed in space is what Richard Serra's distinctive work is about. ----- the black vignetting in the bottom was simply obtained by flash firing onto the top of the frame... Unexpectedly flash can be used in a creative way sometimes :-)) Flickr white background is really shitty with those Monumenta pictures, take your time enjoying "Promenade" On Black.
photo.tags: richardserra monumenta 2008 grand palais paris france nuitdesmusées promenade modernart journalism journalisme
photo.title: Monumenta 2008 : Promenade (Richard Serra)

Jeff Mills mixe au Grand Palais

photo.description: Taken on the Monumenta website : An article about Sculpture today : How might sculpture be defined in the context of modern and contemporary art? What links a work by Richard Serra to the statues of the ancient Greek world? How can we make the transition from a Renaissance Pietà in marble, to Serra's monumental steel sheets? Is a work of sculpture necessarily always figurative or representational? Does it have to be beautiful? What is it for? Contemporary sculpture – frequently disconcerting, often spectacular or on the contrary highly discreet – defies our received ideas of the medium in every way. ----- here my friend Lionel posing against one of the huge monolith. natural vignetting from Canon here, I'm lovin' it :-). Flickr white background is really shitty with those Monumenta pictures, take your time enjoying "Promenade" On Black.
photo.tags: richardserra monumenta 2008 grand palais paris france nuitdesmusées promenade modernart lionelvaraire
photo.title: Monumenta 2008 : Promenade (Richard Serra)
